notesStmt.note: Fragments from liturgical manuscripts reused in eighteenth-century binding as pastedowns inside covers and string guards
Parts of the original text and notation have been erased
Some later annotations in pencil and ink
Fol. 78 has been cut, almost in half
Fragmentary remains of paper tabs in outer margins
J. Thomson, Hither and Thither (Philadelphia, 1905), pp. 135-144.

Supplement to the Census of Medieval and Renaissance Manuscripts in the United States and Canada, originated by C. U. Faye, continued and edited by W. H. Bond (New York: The Bibliographical Society of America, 1962), p. 452, no. 33

msIdentifier.collection: John Frederick Lewis Collection of European Manuscripts

msContents.summary: This Gradual contains liturgical texts and their musical settings for the feasts of saints from Saint Andrew to Saint Clement (fols. 1r-59r) and the Common of Saints (fols. 49r-140v). It is one of a number of large liturgical manuscripts in the collection of the Free Library of Philadelphia (MSS Lewis E 221-234) associated with the Jerónimos Monastery in Belém, near Lisbon. Together, these books may have formed a complete set of choir books for the monastery and, according to the colophons in MSS Lewis E 221 and 222, were paid for by King John III in June 1548. The text of this manuscript is embellished with numerous black and colored initials of varying heights with pen-work decoration. There is a single illuminated initial on fol. 51r, beginning the introit for the feast of Saint Jerome. At least one leaf is missing from the beginning of the book, and perhaps more from the end. Two single leaves were bound into the book (fols. 51 and 72) during or soon after its production. This manuscript preserves its eighteenth century binding, complete with metal bosses and corners and one of its clasps. Inside the front and back covers, fragments from other manuscripts have been used as paste-downs and as string guards. This book's considerable size – over a meter wide when open – would have made it visible to the whole choir during services.

msItem.title: Sanctorale, beginning with Saint Andrew and ending with Saint Clement, beginning lacking

supportDesc.extent: 140; 708 x 540 mm bound to 740 x 565 mm
supportDesc.foliation: Early foliation in red ink, upper right recto, mostly trimmed away; modern foliation in ink, upper right recto; modern foliation in pencil, lower right recto

p.signatures: Modern alphanumeric quire signatures in pencil, inconsistently applied, lower recto

layoutDesc.layout: One column of six lines; five-line staves in red ink; lead point ruling; written area: 625 x 303 mm

decoDesc.decoNote: One illuminated initial, numerous black and colored initials with pen-work decoration
Inside front cover [insert folded]Print catalog clipping
Inside front cover [insert folded]Bookplate, Free Library of Philadelphia
Inside front cover [insert folded]Paper insert with "Alleluia" and musical notation

binding.p: Eighteenth-century stamped dark brown calfskin; metal corners, bosses, and one clasp; edges stained red; sixteenth-century manuscript fragments used as pastedowns inside front and back covers and as string guards

history.provenance: Probably a gift of King John III to the College of St. Jerome in 1548 (along with Free Library MSS Lewis E 212-234, see colophons in first two volumes); Hiersemann of Leipzig (bookseller); bought by the Free Library in 1900; stamped "Geo. S. Pepper Fund 3082" on fol. 1r
